statement.tex:
%text (i) Is the binary operation * defined on set N, given by $a*b=\dfrac{a+b}{2}$ for all a, b $\in$ N, commutative?
(ii) Is the above binary operation * associative? %

step.context: %text Does the following prove that binary operator '$*$' is commutative? %
step.reason: %text By definition of commutativity, binary operator $*$ is commutative if $a*b=b*a$ for any $a,b\in N$. In other words $a*b-b*a=0$ indicates the operator $*$ is commutative. %
\begin{align} a*b-b*a &= \dfrac{a+b}{2}-\dfrac{b+a}{2}=0 \end{align} \\ %text Therefore, the operation $a*b$ is commutative. %

step.context: %text Does the following prove that binary operator * is associative? %
step.reason: %text To prove that binary operator * is associative, we need to show that % \begin{align} &a*(b*c)=(a*b)*c \\ \implies &a*(b*c)-(a*b)*c=0 \end{align} %
